Award.AwardTitle: Triplet Structure and Dynamics in Organometallic Oligomers and Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Kirk S. Schanze of the University of Florida will investigate fundamental properties of carrier transport in conducting polymer molecular wires and thin films. The overall objective of the program is to provide a clear understanding of the structure, energetics and dynamics of triplet exciton states in pi-conjugated, weakly conjugated and non-conjugated model molecular and polymeric chromophore assembliles. The structures that will be the focus of study feature platinum metal units as a primary element. These metal centers serve to enhance triplet spin state generation in the materials and promote room temperature phosphorescence. Understanding the properties of photoexcited states in molecules and polymers with delocalized electronic systems is very important because these materials are receiving a great deal of attention from scientists and engineers for application in a new generation of plastic electronic devices. In particular, the questions addressed in this research program are broadly relevant to applications of organic and organometallic materials in high efficiency light sources (organic light emitting diodes), organic solar cells (light driven electrical power generation), and in control and attenuation of laser light (non-linear optical materials).

This research program provides also serves as key training for postdoc, graduate and undergraduate students in the principal investigator's laboratory. These students obtain broad training in skills ranging from synthetic chemistry to the application of physical methods such as optical spectroscopy and materials characterization. In addition, as part of this project the research group will participate in the Student Science Training Program (SSTP) with a seven-week residential program held each summer at the University of Florida for high school students (11th and 12th graders) interested in careers in science, math and engineering. Each summer the Schanze group will host an SSTP student, getting them involved in the research project, as well as interacting with the full group of SSTP students in seminar and workshop settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project applies synthetic organic and metal-organic chemistry to fabricate new materials that exhibit enhanced optical (light absorption/light emission) and electronic (semiconductor) properties.  The project has the broad goal of understanding how incorporation of heavy metals such as platinum, mercury and gold in an organic semiconductor can modify or enhance the properties.  The heavy metals influence the quantum spin properties of the materials, and this can give rise to benefits with respect to applications in light emitting and energy conversion applications. These applications are pertient to develoment of next generation light emitting devices and solar cells.  Towards this goal, series of related metal-organic chemical structures were synthesized and then the structures were subjected to careful investigation by optical spectroscopy to probe their light absorption and light emission properties.   Selected molecular systems were utilized in device investigations, including organic solar cells and organic transistors.  The results show that the metal units give rise to significantly enhanced generation of triplet spin photoexcitations, and these excitations can be harvested in solar cell application with moderately high energy conversion efficiency.  Several key results were obtained including: 1) A remarkable counter-intuitive trend between the triplet spin conversion efficiency and energy gap for a series of visible light absorbing donor-acceptor chromophores.  2) The efficiency of singlet to triplet spin-conversion in heavy metal conjugated systems depends very much on the molecular architecture. 


Last Modified: 04/28/2016
Modified by: Kirk S Schanze

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project applies synthetic organic and metal-organic chemistry to fabricate new materials that exhibit enhanced optical (light absorption/light emission) and electronic (semiconductor) properties. The project has the broad goal of understanding how incorporation of heavy metals such as platinum, mercury and gold in an organic semiconductor can modify or enhance the properties. The heavy metals influence the quantum spin properties of the materials, and this can give rise to benefits with respect to applications in light emitting and energy conversion applications. These applications are pertient to develoment of next generation light emitting devices and solar cells. Towards this goal, series of related metal-organic chemical structures were synthesized and then the structures were subjected to careful investigation by optical spectroscopy to probe their light absorption and light emission properties. Selected molecular systems were utilized in device investigations, including organic solar cells and organic transistors. The results show that the metal units give rise to significantly enhanced generation of triplet spin photoexcitations, and these excitations can be harvested in solar cell application with moderately high energy conversion efficiency. Several key results were obtained including: 1) A remarkable counter-intuitive trend between the triplet spin conversion efficiency and energy gap for a series of visible light absorbing donor-acceptor chromophores. 2) The efficiency of singlet to triplet spin-conversion in heavy metal conjugated systems depends very much on the molecular architecture.
